questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with hypertension and hypokalemia. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs). Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with her symptoms?

choices.text: Conn syndrome
Liddle syndrome
Glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism (GRA)
Secondary hyperaldosteronism

questions.solution:
Liddle syndrome is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia due to a mutation in the genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs), leading to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.

Liddle Syndrome (Option B)

  • Rare genetic disorder causing high blood pressure and low potassium levels.
  • Caused by a mutation in genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs) in kidneys.
  • Leads to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.

Hyperaldosteronism

  • Characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion.
  • Also a cause of high blood pressure and low potassium levels.
  • Classified into primary and secondary types.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has been on long-term corticosteroid therapy for rheumatoid arthritis. The physician advises tapering the dose gradually rather than stopping it abruptly. What is the reason for this advice?

choices.text: To avoid the risk of adrenal insufficiency
To avoid the risk of Cushing's syndrome
To prevent a sudden increase in blood glucose levels
To prevent sudden increase in blood pressure

questions.solution:
Pituitary-adrenocortical axis takes about 10 months to recover from the suppressive effect of prolonged corticosteroid therapy, which can lead to adrenal insufficiency if steroids are stopped abruptly.

 

Corticosteroid feedback mechanism:

  • Circadian rhythm: Diurnal pattern with peak in morning and low in evening, independent of external factors
  • The adrenal cortex atrophies and becomes unresponsive to the ACTH for about six months after a prolonged treatment with steroids.
  • Adrenal insufficiency is precipitated as a result. (Option A).

Regulation of aldosterone:

(Option B) Cushing's syndrome, (Option C) high blood sugar and (Option D) high blood pressure occur in higher levels of steroid levels in plasma and not in insufficiency.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements are true regarding the action of aldosterone to enhance sodium reabsorption at the molecular level in renal cells?

(a) Inhibits the excretion of K+ to preserve Na+

(b) Activation of sgk gene (serum and glucocorticoid- regulated kinase)

(c) Increases ENaC (Epithelial Na+ Channels) activity

(d) Increases activity of Na+-K+ exchanger

choices.text: a, b, and c
a and c
b, c and d
c and d

questions.solution:
The gene activated by aldosterone is the sgk gene (serum and glucocorticoid- regulated kinase), which increases ENaC (Epithelial Na+ Channels) activity. Aldosterone also stimulates the activity of Na+-K+ exchanger, which increases intracellular accumulation of Na+.

 

Aldosterone Mechanism of action:

  • It has both genomic and nongenomic actions.
  • Aldosterone binds with the cytoplasmic receptor, and the complex moves to the nucleus where it induces transcription of mRNA leading to new protein synthesis that alters cell function.

Genomic Action:

  • The gene activated by aldosterone is the sgk gene (serum and glucocorticoid- regulated kinase). (Statement b)
  • Increases ENaC (Epithelial Na+ Channels) activity (Statement c)
  • Increases insertion of these channels on cell membrane and also increases their activity

Nongenomic Action:

  • It is due to stimulation of the activity of Na+-K+ exchanger (Statement c), which increases intracellular accumulation of Na+.

(Statement a) aldosterone increases amounts of Na+ concentration in exchange for K+ and H+ in the renal tubules, producing a K+ diuresis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary physiological trigger for the suppression of aldosterone secretion?

choices.text: Increased serum potassium levels
Expansion of the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume
Increased renin release
Decreased blood pressure

questions.solution:
Expansion of the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume increases the mean arterial pressure in renal arteries, which inhibits renin thus decreasing the aldosterone secretion.

 

Regulation of aldosterone:

  • Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAS) plays a crucial role in the regulation of aldosterone levels in the plasma.
  • ACTH stimulates aldosterone synthesis and secretion, but the quantity of ACTH required to stimulate aldosterone secretion is more than the concentration required to stimulate cortisol secretion.

Physiological Actions of Aldosterone:

  • The main function of aldosterone is to increase Na+ and water reabsorption and to promote K+ and H+ excretion from the kidney (Option A).
  • It acts primarily on P cells (principal cells) of collecting the duct and distal tubule of the kidney to increase the sodium reabsorption.
  • Chlorine is transported in the same direction to maintain electroneutrality due to Na+ reabsorption, causing osmotic reabsorption of water which leads to ECF expansion (Option B) and increases blood pressure (Option D).
  • (Option D) Increased renin release stimulates aldosterone secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the mechanism by which glucocorticoids regulate metabolic reactions and ACTH secretion?

choices.text: Directly catalyzing metabolic reactions and stimulating ACTH secretion
Binding to glucocorticoid receptors and acting as transcription factors
Inhibiting catecholamine action and decreasing mRNA synthesis
Influence cellular processes by directly altering gene expression.

questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids bind to their receptors, forming complexes that act as transcription factors, promoting the transcription of specific DNA segments, and leading to the synthesis of enzymes that alter cell function.

Glucocorticoids:

  • Production: Steroid hormones produced by the adrenal cortex.
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Bind to glucocorticoid receptors.
    • Form steroid-receptor complexes acting as transcription factors.
    • Promote transcription of specific DNA segments.
    • Lead to synthesis of enzymes altering cell function via mRNA generation. (Option C)
  • Nongenomic Actions: Influence cellular processes without directly affecting gene expression. (Option D)

Permissive Actions (Option A- no direct action)

  • Role in Metabolism: Presence necessary for certain metabolic reactions, though not directly causing them.
    • Calorigenic Effects: Enable glucagon and catecholamines.
    • Lipolytic Effects: Allow catecholamines.
    • Pressor Responses & Bronchodilation: Facilitate actions of catecholamines.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes presents with difficulty managing his blood glucose levels. Which of the following effects of glucocorticoids best explains the patient's difficulty in managing his diabetes?

choices.text: Glucocorticoids enhance the action of insulin in peripheral tissues
Glucocorticoids decrease gluconeogenesis in the liver
Glucocorticoids promote protein anabolism
Glucocorticoids counteract the effects of insulin in peripheral tissues

questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids elevate plasma glucose levels by promoting gluconeogenesis and glycogenesis in the liver and counteracting insulin effects in peripheral tissues, making diabetes management more difficult.

Effects of Glucocorticoids:

Intermediary Metabolism:

  • Promote protein catabolism. (Option C)
  • Stimulate liver glycogenesis and gluconeogenesis. (Option B)
  • Enhance glucose-6-phosphatase activity.
  • Elevates plasma glucose level.
  • Counteract insulin effects in peripheral tissues, worsening diabetes. (Option A) (Option D)
  • In diabetes, elevate plasma lipid levels and promote ketone body formation. In healthy individuals, insulin secretion counters this effect.

Permissive Action:

  • Essential for actions of other hormones (e.g., glucagon and catecholamines).
  • Necessary for catecholamine-induced lipolysis, pressor responses, and bronchodilation.

Effects on ACTH Secretion:

  • Regulate adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion via negative feedback.

Vascular Reactivity:

  • Maintain blood vessel responsiveness to norepinephrine and epinephrine.
  • Deficiency leads to decreased vascular responsiveness, capillary dilation, increased permeability, and potential vascular collapse.

Water Metabolism:

  • Regulate water balance.
  • Adrenal insufficiency impairs water excretion, increasing water intoxication risk.

Blood Cells and Lymphatic Organs:

  • Decrease eosinophils and basophils.
  • Increase neutrophils, platelets, and red blood cells.
  • Decrease lymphocytes and reduce lymph node and thymus size.

Stress Resistance:

  • Crucial for stress response.
  • Stress induces ACTH secretion, increasing glucocorticoid levels essential for survival.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of hypertension and hypokalemia. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of aldosterone.Which of the following statements is true regarding the enzyme and the zone responsible for producing aldosterone?

choices.text: Aldosterone is produced in the zona fasciculata, and the key enzyme involved is 17α-Hydroxylase
Aldosterone is synthesized from pregnenolone via progesterone in the zona glomerulosa
In the zona reticularis, pregnenolone is converted to aldosterone by Aldosterone Synthase
The zona glomerulosa produces aldosterone directly from cholesterol, bypassing pregnenolone and progesterone

questions.solution:
In the zona glomerulosa, pregnenolone is first transformed into progesterone, which is then further converted into aldosterone through several enzymatic steps. The final conversion to aldosterone is catalyzed by aldosterone synthase (P450c11AS or CYP11B2), an enzyme specific to this zona.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with signs of early virilization and ambiguous genitalia. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ACTH and 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?

choices.text: 11β-hydroxylase deficiency
21β-hydroxylase deficiency
3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency
17α-hydroxylase deficiency

questions.solution:
21β-hydroxylase deficiency leads to reduced cortisol and aldosterone production, causing elevated ACTH and increased production of androgens, resulting in virilization and ambiguous genitalia.

 

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

  • Definition: Group of genetic disorders affecting adrenal glands, causing enzyme deficiencies in steroid biosynthesis.
  • Effects: Disruption in cortisol and aldosterone production, leading to various symptoms.
  • Prevalence: Most common deficiency is 21β-hydroxylase deficiency (90%+ cases).

21β-Hydroxylase Deficiency

  • Impact: Reduced cortisol and aldosterone production.
  • Consequence: Increased ACTH secretion. (Option B)
  • Result: Increased precursor steroids converted to androgens → Virilization.

Other Enzyme Deficiencies in CAH

Enzyme Deficiency

Description

Symptoms/Consequences

Cholesterol desmolase deficiency

Fatal in utero, prevents placental progesterone synthesis.

Death before birth.

Steroidogenic acute regulatory (StAR) protein deficiency

Known as congenital lipoid adrenal hyperplasia. Prevents cholesterol movement into mitochondria.

Low steroid production, female genitalia regardless of genetic sex.

3β-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency

Increases DHEA secretion (weak androgen).

Masculinization in females, hypospadias in males. (Option C)

17α-Hydroxylase deficiency

Caused by mutated CYP17 gene. Prevents sex hormone production.

Female external genitalia, hypertension, hypokalemia due to high 11-deoxycorticosterone. (Option D- not early virilization)

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

Increased 11-deoxycortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone secretion.

Virilization, hypertension due to salt and water retention. (Option A)

Treatment

  • Glucocorticoid treatment: Recommended for all virilizing forms of CAH.
    • Purpose: Addresses glucocorticoid deficit.
    • Effect: Inhibits ACTH secretion, reducing androgen and steroid production.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman exhibits positive Chvostek's and Trousseau's signs. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Increased ionized calcium levels due to hyperventilation
Decreased ionized calcium levels.
Increased total calcium levels due to chronic kidney diseas
Decreased total calcium levels due to vitamin D overdose

questions.solution:
Alkalosis, which can occur due to hyperventilation or other factors, leads to more calcium binding to albumin, thereby decreasing the levels of free-ionized calcium. This reduction in ionized calcium increases neuromuscular excitability, resulting in symptoms like muscle cramps and tingling sensations and positive Chvostek's and Trousseau's signs.


 

Total Body Calcium Regulation:

  • Primary Reservoir: Bone acts as the main calcium reservoir.

 

Serum calcium normal range = 8.5-10.5 mg/dL

 

Forms of ECF Calcium:

  • Ionized Calcium (50%): Most physiologically important form, influencing heart, nervous system, and bone formation.
  • Protein-bound Calcium (41%): Bound to plasma proteins like albumin.
  • Anion-bound Calcium (9%): Bound to anions in the ECF.

 

Binding Dynamics of Calcium and Hydrogen Ions:

Acidosis:

Competition with Hydrogen Ions: Hydrogen ions compete with calcium for binding sites on albumin, increasing levels of free calcium.

Alkalosis: (option B)

Increased Binding of Calcium: More calcium binds to albumin, reducing free calcium levels and increasing excitability.

 

Other options:

Option A and C) Increased calcium would not lead to symptoms of neuromuscular excitability

Option D) Vitamin D overdose would cause increased calcium levels

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency department with symptoms of muscle spasms and difficulty breathing. She has recently been hyperventilating due to anxiety and reports a tingling sensation in her fingers. On examination, she exhibits a positive Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism of tetany in this patient?

choices.text: Increased calcium absorption due to high levels of parathyroid hormone
Decreased ionized calcium leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells
Increased protein ionization due to low pH causing more free Ca2+ availability
Enhanced bone calcium mobilization from decreased parathyroid hormone levels

questions.solution:
Tetany is primarily caused by a decrease in extracellular ionized calcium (Ca2+). This reduction increases the excitability of nerve and muscle cells, leading to symptoms such as muscle spasms and laryngospasm.

 

Tetany:

  • It is characterized by extensive skeletal muscle spasms
  • Cause: Decrease in extracellular ionized calcium (Ca2+), leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells.
  • Mechanism:

Increased Excitability: Reduced extracellular Ca2+ lowers its binding to voltage-gated sodium channels in nerve and muscle cells.

Action Potential Generation: Lower Ca2+ binding decreases the activation threshold of these channels, making them more likely to open and trigger action potentials.

  • Complication: Laryngospasm can obstruct the airway and potentially cause fatal asphyxia.

 

Calcium and Tetany:

  • Normal Total Calcium Levels: Total calcium might appear normal, but a decrease in ionized calcium can still cause tetany.
  • Influence of pH: Increased pH (alkalosis) from hyperventilation increases plasma protein ionization, binding more Ca2+ and reducing free Ca2+ availability.

 

Signs of Tetany:

  • Chvostek Sign: Contraction of facial muscles upon tapping the facial nerve.
  • Trousseau Sign: Spasm of upper extremity muscles, causing wrist and thumb flexion with finger extension; elicited by occluding circulation with a blood pressure cuff.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding parathyroid hormone (PTH) and calcium regulation is TRUE?

choices.text: PTH promotes calcium reabsorption and phosphate absorption in the renal tubules
PTH directly enhances calcium absorption in the intestines by increasing the expression of calcium-binding proteins
PTH directly activates osteoclasts, which break down bone tissue and release calcium into the extracellular fluid
PTH is essential for the conversion of inactive vitamin D to its active form

questions.solution:
PTH acts as a key regulator, preventing calcium levels from falling too low and maintaining a stable calcium concentration in the extracellular fluid, even in the face of fluctuations in calcium intake or loss.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary role of vitamin D in calcium regulation?

choices.text: Vitamin D directly stimulates osteoclast activity to release calcium from bones
Vitamin D enhances calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, reducing its excretion
Vitamin D increases the production of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which mobilizes calcium
Vitamin D facilitates the intestinal absorption of calcium, increasing its uptake from food

questions.solution:
Correct answer (D) Vitamin D facilitates the intestinal absorption of calcium, increasing its uptake from food .

The main role of vitamin D in calcium regulation is to enhance calcium absorption in the intestines along with potassium reabsorption. This increases the serum calcium and potassium concentration.. Lack of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, in turn, decreases absorption of calcium from the intestines, bones, and renal tubules, thus causing the calcium ion concentration to fall back .

 

Active Vitamin D production:

Actions of 1,25-Dihydroxycholecalciferol

Action site

Key concepts

Intestines
  • Increases the production of calbindin (calcium-binding protein) in intestinal epithelial cells which increases calcium absorption.

Kidneys
  • Increases calcium and phosphate reabsorption in the renal tubules, reducing their excretion in urine.
  • This effect is relatively weak

Bones
  • Excessive vitamin D can cause bone resorption.
  • Smaller quantities actually promote bone calcification.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the primary mechanism by which calcitonin lowers blood calcium levels?

choices.text: Stimulates osteoblast activity to build new bone tissue
Increases the absorption of calcium in the intestines
Inhibits osteoclast activity to reduce bone resorption
Enhances the reabsorption of calcium in the kidneys

questions.solution:
Calcitonin is a hormone produced by the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland that plays a crucial role in regulating calcium homeostasis. Its primary mechanism for lowering blood calcium levels involves inhibiting the activity of osteoclasts, which are the cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue (bone resorption)

Calcitonin:

  • A hormone produced by the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland.
  • Its primary function is to lower blood calcium levels (hypocalcemic effect).

Calcium Regulation:

  • Calcitonin helps to regulate calcium levels in the blood, working in opposition to parathyroid hormone (PTH), which increases blood calcium levels.


 

Mechanism of Action

Action site

Key concepts

Bone
  • Inhibition of Osteoclast Activity by binding to calcitonin receptors on osteoclast (Option A) and (Option C)
  • Decreased release of calcium and phosphate from bone

  • Increased Calcium Excretion (Option D)

  • Reduces the reabsorption of calcium and phosphate in the renal tubules.

Intestine

  • Decreased Calcium Absorption (Minor Role) (Option B)

  • Effect is less compared to kidney


Secretion Triggers:

  • High blood calcium levels
  • Gastrin and pentagastrin (hormones involved in digestion)
